title: 114_s2989
content: The Act may be cited as the "Merchant Mariners of World War II Congressional Gold Medal Act of 2016". Congress acknowledges the vital role played by the United States Merchant Marine in World War II, providing essential support to the Allied victory as recognized by Fleet Admiral Ernest J. King and President Dwight D. Eisenhower. During World War II, the American Merchant Marine played a crucial role in strengthening the forces of freedom by efficiently transporting military equipment and personnel despite facing constant threats from enemy combatants. During World War II, the American Merchant Marine faced threats at sea but proved to be instrumental in various military operations, including supplying material for the invasion of Normandy. General Eisenhower praised their performance, highlighting their crucial role in Allied command. During World War II, General Eisenhower and President Roosevelt praised the loyalty, courage, and efficiency of the Merchant Marine, highlighting their vital role in delivering goods across dangerous theaters of operations. The feats of the Merchant Marine deserve greater public recognition, and the United States will always be grateful for their service. The United States is grateful to merchant mariners for their courageous transport of goods in enemy territory during World War II, which saved lives and contributed to Allied victory. A Congressional Gold Medal would honor their service and role in the war. A Congressional Gold Medal would honor their service and role in the war. SEC. 3. CONGRESSIONAL GOLD MEDAL. The Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate will arrange for a gold medal to be awarded to US merchant mariners of World War II. The Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike the medal. After the award, it will be given to the American Merchant Marine Museum for display and research. The American Merchant Marine Museum will receive a gold medal awarded to US merchant mariners of World War II for display and research. Congress suggests making the medal available for display at locations associated with the United States Merchant Marine. The Secretary may strike and sell duplicates of the gold medal in bronze under regulations, covering costs. Medals are considered national medals and numismatic items under specific codes.
